message.content:
We need to find how much tax “remained” (or “net‐accrued”) as a liability in this period – in other words the “Increase (Decrease) in Tax Payable”. In these transactions the only entries that carry a “tax_amount” are on sale transactions. (Other kinds of transactions – expenses, purchases, depreciation, etc.—do not show tax‐amount values.) A common way to “build” the tax payable item is to add up the tax amounts reported on the sales (which, if not “paid” immediately to the tax authority, become a liability – that is “tax payable”). (In reality, a full calculation might take into account any recovered credits on purchases, but in our given tables the only tax numbers are on sales.) 

Thus we “scan” the rows of type “Sale” and sum their tax_amounts. In the provided data the sale entries with a tax_amount are as follows:

1. Sale20240102001:  tax_amount = 14,211.55 
2. Sale20240102002:  tax_amount = 13,744.75 
3. Sale20240103004:  tax_amount = 14,351.09 
4. Sale20240106006:  tax_amount = 9,033.06 
5. Sale20240107008:  tax_amount =    102.09 
6. Sale20240108010:  tax_amount = 14,296.14 
7. Sale20240110012:  tax_amount =    96.27 
8. Sale20240110013:  tax_amount = 14,792.99 
9. Sale20240111015:  tax_amount =   110.62 
10. Sale20240111016:  tax_amount = 13,864.35 
11. Sale20240111017:  tax_amount = 9,660.20 
12. Sale20240112018:  tax_amount =    687.96 
13. Sale20240123031:  tax_amount =   119.21 
14. Sale20240127036:  tax_amount =   110.18 
15. Sale20240128037:  tax_amount = 12,062.97 
16. Sale20240128038:  tax_amount = 13,246.94 
17. Sale20240130040:  tax_amount = 10,820.26 
18. Sale20240130041:  tax_amount = 13,612.26 
19. Sale20240130042:  tax_amount =    115.65 
20. Sale20240131044:  tax_amount = 12,058.41 
21. Sale20240131045:  tax_amount =    112.79 
22. Sale20240204049:  tax_amount =    594.84 
23. Sale20240205052:  tax_amount = 2,076.40 

Adding these up step‐by‐step:

• 14,211.55 + 13,744.75 = 27,956.30  
• + 14,351.09 = 42,307.39  
• + 9,033.06  = 51,340.45  
• +    102.09 = 51,442.54  
• + 14,296.14 = 65,738.68  
• +    96.27 = 65,834.95  
• + 14,792.99 = 80,627.94  
• +   110.62 = 80,738.56  
• + 13,864.35 = 94,602.91  
• + 9,660.20  =104,263.11  
• +    687.96 =104,951.07  
• +    119.21 =105,070.28  
• +    110.18 =105,180.46  
• + 12,062.97 =117,243.43  
• + 13,246.94 =130,490.37  
• + 10,820.26 =141,310.63  
• + 13,612.26 =154,922.89  
• +    115.65 =155,038.54  
• + 12,058.41 =167,096.95  
• +    112.79 =167,209.74  
• +    594.84 =167,804.58  
• + 2,076.40  =169,880.98  

So the total tax amount that has “accrued” on sales is 169,880.98. (If there are no adjustments or payments of tax during the period, then the tax payable – the increase in the liability – is this same amount.)

Thus the final cash‐flow “increase (decrease) in tax payable” is 169,880.98.

We can now return the answer in the requested JSON format:

---------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "Increase (Decrease) in Tax Payable": "169880.98"
  }
}
